data.title: Historical Figures Born on March 26
data.meta_description: Famous birthdays in history for the 26th of March. See which explorers, inventors and historical figures were born on March 26.
data.text:
Vasili III of Russia, Great Prince of Moscow (1505-33), son of Ivan III (d. 1533)

Conrad Gessner, Swiss physician and naturalist, born in Zürich, Switzerland (d. 1565)

Charles, Duke of Mayenne, French military leader, born in Alençon, France (d. 1611)

Václav Prokop Diviš, Czech theologian and natural scientist, born in Helvíkovice, Bohemia (d. 1765)

William Blount, American statesman and signer of the United States Constitution, born in Windsor, North Carolina (d. 1800)

Benjamin Thompson, American physicist and inventor (Royal Institution of Great Britain), born in Woburn, Massachusetts (d. 1814)

Nathaniel Bowditch, American mathematician, astronomer and author (Marine Sextant), born in Salem, Province of Massachusetts Bay (d. 1838)

Julius Schnorr von Carolsfeld, German painter and designer who figured importantly in the German Nazarene movement, born in Leipzig, Saxony (d. 1872)

Thomas West Sherman, American Brevet Major General (Union Army), born in Newport, Rhode Island (d. 1879)

Herman Haupt, American civil engineer and Brigadier General (Union Army), born in Philadelphia, Pennsylvania (d. 1905)

Louise Otto-Peters, German suffragist, women's rights movement activist and author (The Wandering Star), born in Meissen, Germany (d. 1895)

Ernst Engel, German statistician and economist (Law of Engel), born in Dresden, Kingdom of Saxony (d. 1896)

Eliza Laurillard, Dutch vicar, poet and writer, born in Rotterdam, Netherlands (d. 1908)

Betsy Perk [Christina Elizabeth], Dutch journalist, writer and pioneer of the Dutch women's movement, born in Delft, Netherlands (d. 1906)

George Smith, English archaeologist and assyriologist (cuneiform script), born in London (d. 1876)

Edward Bellamy, American author (Looking Backward) and socialist, born in Chicopee, Massachusetts (d. 1898)

David Alfred Thomas, 1st Viscount Rhondda, Welsh coal-mining entrepreneur, born in Ysgyborwen, Wales (d. 1918)

A. E. Housman, English poet (A Shropshire Lad), born in Bromsgrove, Worcestershire, England (d. 1936)

1859 Adolf Hurwitz, German mathematician (Riemann–Hurwitz formula), born in Hildesheim, Germany (d. 1919)

Fuʾād I [Aḥmad Fuʾād Pasha], King of Egypt (1922-36), born in Cairo, Egypt (d. 1936)

Jonah Kūhiō Kalaniana'ole, Prince of the Kingdom of Hawaii, born in Kukui‘ula, Kōloa, Kauaʻi, Kingdom of Hawaii (d. 1922)

Robert Frost

American poet (Mending Wall, Road Not Taken), born in San Francisco, California

Syngman Rhee

1st President of South Korea (1948-60), born in Haeju, North Korea

Prince William of Wied, Prince of Albania (1914-25), born in Neuwied, German Empire (d. 1945)

Othmar Ammann, Swiss-American bridge engineer (George Washington Bridge; Walt Whitman Bridge; Verrazzano-Narrows Bridge), born in Schaffhausen, Switzerland (d. 1965)

Duncan Hines, American restaurant guide writer (Out of Kentucky Kitchens), born in Bowling Green, Kentucky (d. 1959)

Guccio Gucci, Italian founder of Gucci fashion house, born in Florence, Italy (d. 1953)

Hermann Obrecht, Swiss jurist, member of the Swiss Federal Council, born in Grenchen, Switzerland (d. 1940)

Robert Blackburn, British aviation pioneer and the founder of Blackburn Aircraft, born in Kirkstall, Leeds (d. 1955)

Hugh Mulzac, America military officer (d. 1971)

Elsa Brändström, Swedish nurse who helped POWs in Siberia, born in Saint Petersburg, Russia. (d. 1948)

Jozef Arras, Flemish writer, born in Lier (d. 1919)

James B. Conant, American chemist and President of Harvard University, born in Dorchester, Massachusetts (d. 1978)

Palmiro Togliatti

Italian politician and General Secretary of the Communist Party of Italy (1926-34, 1938-64), born in Genoa, Italy

James B. Connant, American chemist, President of Harvard and diplomat, born in Dorchester, Massachusetts (d. 1978)

Leslie Melville, Australian economist and public servant who helped develop the country's central banking system, born in Sydney, Australia (d. 2002)

Emilio Fernandez, Mexican director (La Choca, Flor Silvestre), born in El Seco Mexico (d. 1986)

1904 Joseph Campbell, American professor of comparative mythology (Mythic Image), born in White Plains, New York (d. 1987)

1904 Xenophon Zolotas, Greek economist, Prime Minister of Greece (d. 2004)

Viktor Frankl, Austrian neurologist and psychiatrist (Man's Search for Meaning) and founder of logotherapy, born in Vienna, Austria-Hungary (d. 1997)

Rafael Mendez, Mexican trumpetist (d. 1981)

Mahadevi Varma, Indian poet and freedom fighter, born in Farrukhabad, British India (d. 1987)

Betty MacDonald [nee Bard], American humor writer (The Egg and I), in Boulder, Colorado (d. 1958)

1908 Kenneth Mellanby, English entomologist (scabies) (d. 1993)

Bernard Katz, German-born Australian biophysicist (Nobel Prize in Physiology or Medicine 1970), born in Leipzig, German Empire (d. 2003)

Tennessee Williams

American playwright (A Streetcar Named Desire, Cat on a Hot Tin Roof), born in Columbus, Mississippi

Paul Erdős, Hungarian mathematician, born in Budapest, Austria-Hungary (d. 1996)

Ian McGeoch, Scottish Vice-Admiral with Royal Navy (submarine HMS Splendid WWII), born in Helensburgh, Scotland (d. 2007)

1914 Toru Kumon, Japanese mathematics educator (Kumon Institute of Education,), born in Kōchi Prefecture, Japan (d. 1995)

William Westmoreland

American general and commander of American forces in the Vietnam War between 1964-68, born in Saxon, South Carolina

Christian B. Anfinsen, American chemist (cell physiology, Nobel 1972), born in Monessen, Pennsylvania (d. 1995)

1916 Mort Abrahams, American producer (Dr Doolittle, Planet Of Apes), born in New York (d. 2009)

George Brown Jr, American politician (Rep-D-CA, 1963-71, 73-99), born in Holtsville, California (d. 1999)

George Jefferson, English engineer who oversaw privatisation of British Telecom, born in Kent, England (d. 2012) [1]

Oscar Sala, Italian-born Brazilian nuclear physicist, born in Milan, Italy (d. 2010)

1922 William Milliken, American politician, longest serving Governor of Michigan (1969-83), born in Traverse City, Michigan (d. 2019)

Elizabeth Jane Howard, British novelist (After Julius), (d. 2014)

1923 Gert Bastian, German military officer and politician (co-founder of German Green Party), born in Munich, Germany (d. 1992)

Baron Hooson [Hugh Emlyn], British politician and peer (MP for Montgomeryshire 1962-79), (d. 2012)

1925 Ted Graham, Lord Graham of Edmonton, English politician, House of Lords (chief opposition whip), born in Newcastle upon Tyne, England (d. 2020)

Gregory Corso, American beat poet (Happy Birthday of Death, Long Live Man), born in New York City (d. 2001)

Sandra Day O'Connor

American 1st woman Supreme Court Justice (1981- 2006), born in El Paso, Texas [1]

Mahmoud Abbas

2nd President of the Palestine National Authority (2005-present), born in Safed, Mandatory Palestine

Anthony James Leggett, English physicist, (Nobel Prize for Physics 2013 for superfluidity), born in London, England

Colin Webb, British fleet street editor and journalist (Press Association) (d. 2013)

1939 Jonathan Tod, British Vice-Admiral (Royal Navy)

1939 Stuart Sutherland, British psychologist, educator (Sussex University), and writer (Breakdown) (d. 1998)

Nancy Pelosi

American politician (Rep-D-California 1987-), 1st female Speaker of the House (2007-11, 2019-), born in Baltimore, Maryland

Richard Dawkins, British evolutionary biologist (The God Delusion), born in Nairobi, Kenya Colony

1941 Yvon Marcoux, Quebec politician, born in Lévis, Quebec

Erica Jong [Mann], American author (Fear of Flying), born in New York City

Bob Woodward

American author and investigative reporter (Watergate, CIA crimes), born in Geneva Illinois

John Harries, British atmospheric physicist (provided 1st direct observational evidence of carbon dioxide increase - greenhouse effect), born in Sedgefield, England (d. 2022) [1]

Dar Robinson, American stuntman, born in Los Angeles, California (d. 1986)

Baroness Hayman [Helene Hayman], British politician (Lord Speaker of the House of Lords, 2006-11), born in Wolverhampton, West Midlands

David Amess, British politician (C), born in London

1952 Yoshitaka Amano, Japanese visual artist and illustrator (Final Fantasy), born in Shizuoka City, Japan

Elaine Chao, American politician (U.S. Secretary of Transportaion, 2017-21; U.S. Secretary of Labor, 2001-2009), born in Taipei, Taiwan

1953 Lincoln Chafee, American politician (Governor of Rhode Island, 2011-15; US Senator (R) - Rhode Island, 1999-2007), born in Providence, Rhode Island

1953 Youssouf Togoïmi, Chadian rebel (d. 2002)

Piers Gardner, British human rights lawyer (British Institute of Intl & Comparative Law)

Leigh Bowery, Australian performance artist and designer, born in Sunshine, Australia (d. 1996)

1961 William Hague, English politician, Secretary of State, Leader of the Opposition, born in Rotherham, England

Yuri Pavlovich Gidzenko, Ukrainian-Russian Air Force pilot and officer, and cosmonaut Mir; International Space Station), born in Elanets, Ukrainian SSR, Soviet Union

Natsuhiko Kyogoku, Japanese writer (Mōryō no Hako), born in Hokkaido, Japan

Behzad Ghorbani, Iranian zoologist and sociobiologist

Larry Page

American computer scientist and businessman (co-founded Google with Sergey Brin), born in East Lansing, Michigan

Jessica McClure, American baby rescued after being trapped in a well in Texas (1987), born in Midland, Texas

Paige VanZant, American mixed martial artist, born in Dundee, Oregon
